children_exceptions.name: Germany: entry rules for children
children_exceptions.conditions: Travellers under 6 years of age do not need to present a Covid test result on entry.

children_exceptions.name: Germany: local rules for children
children_exceptions.conditions: The regulations in which situations and from what age mouth and nose coverings or other masks are mandatory for children may differ depending on the  federal state.

children_exceptions.name: Luxembourg: entry rules for children
children_exceptions.conditions: Children younger than 6 years old travelling to Luxembourg by air do not need to make a Covid test to enter the country.

children_exceptions.name: Luxembourg: local rules for children
children_exceptions.conditions: Children under 6 years old are not required to wear masks in public spaces.

children_exceptions.name: Netherlands: entry rules for children
children_exceptions.conditions: Childeren younger than 13 years of age do not need to present negative Covid test results on entry.

entry_regulations.name: Germany: less than 24h OR transport sector worker OR transit
entry_regulations.conditions: No special special requirements upon entry apply.

entry_regulations.name: Germany: entry for work AND more than 24h
entry_regulations.conditions: You need to fill out a registration form before entry. You can find the digital version at: www.einreiseanmeldung.de

entry_regulations.name: Germany: entry for leisure AND more than 24h
entry_regulations.conditions: You must do the following: fill out a registration form at www.einreiseanmeldung.de; have a SARS-CoV-2 test result in the period of 48h after entry. The test must no older than 48 hours before entry. You should quarantine for ten days upon arrival but can finish the quarantine after the fifth day by presenting a negative covid test result.

entry_regulations.name: Luxembourg: travel by land OR transit OR transport sector worker
entry_regulations.conditions: You do not need to quarantine, present a negative Covid test or any additional documents upon your travel to Luxembourg.

entry_regulations.name: Luxembourg: travel by air OR NOT transport sector worker
entry_regulations.conditions: You must present a negative COVID-19 test result at boarding, it should be not older than 72 hours.

entry_regulations.name: The Netherlands: (work AND (physical presence||short trip)) OR (family AND going by car)
entry_regulations.conditions: No special special requirements upon entry apply.

entry_regulations.name: The Netherlands: (work AND remote) OR (leisure AND going by car)
entry_regulations.conditions: You must self-quarantine for 10 days upon your arrival. You can get tested again on day 5 after your arrival. If the result is negative you can end your self-quarantine.

entry_regulations.name: The Netherlands: family AND going by coach
entry_regulations.conditions: You must present a negative NAAT (PCR) test result of a test made 72 hours before arrival.

entry_regulations.name: The Netherlands: leisure AND going by coach
entry_regulations.conditions: You must present a negative NAAT (PCR) test result of a test made 72 hours before arrival. You must self-quarantine for 10 days upon arriving. You can get tested again on day 5 after your arrival and end your self-quarantine if the result is negative.

entry_regulations.name: The Netherlands: leisure AND plane
entry_regulations.conditions: You must prove that you tested negative for Covid-19. There are two options to do this. 1)You can present a PCR test result of a test made 12 hours before boarding. 2)You can present both a PCR test result of a test made 72 hours before arrival and a rapid test result based on a sample collected 4 hours before boarding. You must self-quarantine for 10 days upon arriving in the Netherlands. You can get tested again on day 5 after your arrival and end your self-quarantine if the result is negative. In addition, you should complete a health declaration which can be found at https: www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/documents/publications/2020/07/07/information-for-passengers-flying-to-and-from-the-netherlands.

entry_regulations.name: The Netherlands: family AND going by plane
entry_regulations.conditions: You must prove that you tested negative for Covid-19. There are two options to do this. 1)You can present a NAAT (PCR) test result of a test made 12 hours before boarding. 2)You can present both a NAAT (PCR) test result of a test made 72 hours before arrival and a rapid test result of a test made 4 hours before boarding. In addition, you should complete a health declaration which can be found at https:www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/documents/publications/2020/07/07/information-for-passengers-flying-to-and-from-the-netherlands.

details.name: Germany, test
details.conditions: You must have a SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus test result in paper electronic form in English, French or German in the period of 48h after entry. The test must have been performed no more than 48 hours prior to entry (time of swabbing). You must keep the result for at least ten days after entry.

details.name: Luxembourg, test
details.conditions: Accepted tests are: PCR (polymerase chain reaction), TAM (transcription-mediated amplification) or LAMP (loop-mediated isothermal amplification); or of a viral antigen test (in line with the World Health Organization criteria: Antigen-detection in the diagnosis of SARS-CoV-2 infection using rapid immunoassays, Interim Guidance, 11 September 2020). The test result must be in either in one of the administrative languages of Luxembourg, or in English, Spanish, Italian or Portuguese.

details.name: Netherlands, test
details.conditions: The negative test result must be in English, German, French, Italian, Portuguese, Spanish or Dutch and include the following information: type of test, which must be a molecular NAAT (PCR) test (either PCR, RT PCR, LAMP, TMA or mPOCT); your name and surname as stated in your passport; date and time you were tested; name and contact information of the institute or laboratory that conducted the test.

local_regulations.name: Germany: outdoor covid regulations
local_regulations.conditions: Outdoors: In Germany, certain regulations on the outdoors may vary in the federal states. When planning your trip, it is best to check with the local regulations of a respective state.

local_regulations.name: Germany: indoor covid regulations
local_regulations.conditions: Indoors: You should wear a mask in in any public transport, as well as inside stores and busy outdoor places. Masks must be FFP2, KN95/N95 or surgical masks.

local_regulations.name: Germany: all local covid regulations
local_regulations.conditions: Indoors: You should wear a mask in public transport, as well as inside stores and busy outdoor places. Masks must be FFP2, KN95/N95 or surgical masks. In Germany, certain regulations may vary in the federal states. When planning your trip, it is best to check with the local regulations of a respective state.

local_regulations.name: Luxembourg: outdoor AND going_to_work AND one_household
local_regulations.conditions: Outdoors: No relevant rules apply to you outdoors.

local_regulations.name: Luxembourg: outdoor AND going_to_work
local_regulations.conditions: Outdoors: For an outside gathering from 5 to 10 people masks and a 2-meter distance are required.

local_regulations.name: Luxembourg: outdoor AND one_household
local_regulations.conditions: Outdoors: Between 11 p.m. and 6 a.m. the curfew applies and you cannot drink alcohol in public places.

local_regulations.name: Luxembourg: outdoor AND NOT one_household
local_regulations.conditions: Outdoors: Between 11 p.m. and 6 a.m. the curfew applies. Drinking alcohol in public is prohibited. For an outside gathering from 5 to 10 people masks and a 2m distance are required.

local_regulations.name: Luxembourg: indoor
local_regulations.conditions: Indoors: You have to wear a mask during all activities open to the public, in all closed spaces and on public transport. There are no restrictions on the type of mask to wear.

local_regulations.name: The Netherlands: outdoor AND going_to_work AND one_household
local_regulations.conditions: Outdoors: No relevant rules apply to you outdoors.

local_regulations.name: The Netherlands: outdoor AND going_to_work
local_regulations.conditions: Outdoors: You are exempted from curfew, however, no more than one person can go somewhere together with you, except for children under 13.

local_regulations.name: The Netherlands: outdoor AND one_household
local_regulations.conditions: Outdoors: Between 20:00 and 06:00 you may not drink alcohol or have it on you in public spaces. From 21:00 until 04:30 curfew applies.

local_regulations.name: The Netherlands: outdoor AND NOT one_household
local_regulations.conditions: Outdoors: Between 20:00 and 06:00 you may not drink alcohol or have it on you in public spaces. From 21:00 until 04:30 curfew applies. No more than one person can go somewhere together with you, except for children under 13.

local_regulations.name: The Netherlands: indoor
local_regulations.conditions: Indoors: You should wear a mask in all public spaces and covered areas. This includes educational institutions, public transport and locations where contact-based professions are carried out, as well as shops, town halls and train stations. You can buy or make your own face mask for general use.

local_regulations.name: Germany: open places
local_regulations.conditions: All nonessential shops and services remain closed.

local_regulations.name: Luxembourg: open places
local_regulations.conditions: All shops are open. Restaurants, bars and cafes are closed.

local_regulations.name: Netherlands: open places
local_regulations.conditions: Most indoor public spaces are closed. This applies to all non-essential shops, entertainment venues, cafes and restaurants.
